What is the function of the immune system?

The immune system is the body’s defense network that protects us from harmful invaders, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites. It identifies and neutralizes threats while distinguishing them from the body’s own healthy cells.

Innate immunity is the body’s first line of defense and is present from birth. It provides rapid, non-specific protection against pathogens and includes physical barriers, chemical defenses, and cellular defenses.

Adaptive immunity develops over time as the body encounters and learns to recognize specific pathogens. It involves specialized cells, such as B cells and T cells, and has memory, meaning it can respond more rapidly and effectively upon subsequent exposures to the same pathogen.
What is the role of the lymphatic system in immune defense?

The lymphatic system is a network of vessels, nodes, and organs that plays a central role in immune defense. It filters foreign particles and houses immune cells, removes damaged cells and pathogens, and helps transport immune cells and signals throughout the body.
What happens during an inflammatory response?

When the immune system detects an invasion or tissue damage, it triggers an inflammatory response. This involves increased blood flow, swelling, redness, and heat in the affected area, bringing immune cells to the site of infection or injury and facilitating healing.

Autoimmune disorders occur when the immune system mistakenly attacks the body’s own healthy cells. Examples include type 1 diabetes, multiple sclerosis, and rheumatoid arthritis. These conditions occur when immune tolerance is lost.

Vaccines expose the body to harmless forms or pieces of pathogens, prompting the adaptive immune system to develop memory cells without causing disease. This allows for faster, stronger responses during future exposures, greatly reducing the risk of severe illness.
